    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Using a Mobile Phone (Cell Phone) in Any Nation",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Try 911 or 112. These numbers work with many mobile service providers worldwide, due to efforts by the European Union and the United States. Try these first, unless a local knows a number that will work on mobile phones."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "If that fails look up the emergency services number by continent and country below:\n\nAfrica\nAsia and Oceania\nEurope\nCentral and South America\nMiddle East\n\nNorth America and Caribbean"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "African Emergency Numbers",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Northern Africa. These countries cover the Saharan desert and all African land north of it:\n\n\nAlgeria:\nAmbulance: 021 \u2013 23 63 81 or 021 \u2013 71 14 14\nPolice: 17 (or 021 \u2013 73 53 50 from a mobile)\nFire: 14 (or 021 \u2013 71 14 14 from a mobile)\n\n\nCanary Islands: 112\n\nEgypt:\nAmbulance: 123\nPolice: 122\nFire: 180\n\n\nLibya: 193 (currently unreliable)\n\n\nMorocco:\nAmbulance or Fire: 15\nPolice: 19\n\n\nSudan: Only local numbers available\n\nTunisia:\nAmbulance: 190\nPolice: 197\nFire: 198"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Eastern Africa. Here are emergency numbers for the Horn of Africa, and countries along the eastern half of Africa, including Madagascar.\n\n\nBurundi: Only local numbers available\n\nDjibouti:\nAmbulance: 19\nPolice: 17\nFire: 18\n\n\nEritrea: Only local numbers available\n\nEthiopia:\nAmbulance: 92\nPolice: 91\nFire: 93\n\n\nKenya:\nAll emergencies: 999\n\n\nMadagascar:\nAmbulance: 124\nPolice: 117\nFire: 118\nTraffic Accidents: 3600\n\n\nMalawi:\nAmbulance: 998\nPolice: 997 or 990\nFire: 999\n\n\nMauritius:\nAmbulance: 114\nPolice: 112 or 999\nFire: 115 or 995\n\n\nMozambique:\nAmbulance: 117\nPolice: 119\nFire: 198\n\n\nRwanda:\n\nAmbulance: 912\n\nPolice and Fire: 112\n\n\nSomalia: (may be unreliable or absent in some regions)[1][2]Ambulance: 999\nPolice: 888\nFire: 555\n\n\nSouth Sudan:\nPolice: 777 (in Juba only)[3]\nAmbulance and Fire: Unavailable\n\n\nTanzania: (may be unreliable; try local numbers)\nAmbulance: 115\nPolice: 112\nFire: 114\n\n\nUganda: 999\n\nZambia: 999 or 991\n\nZimbabwe:\nAmbulance: 994\nPolice: 777-777 (leads to Harare Central Station)\n\nFire: 993 or 783-983\nMedical Air Relief: 771-221"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Central Africa. Look here for information on countries in Central Africa, and on the central western coast. (See Western Africa below for countries along the northwest coast.)\n\n\nAngola:[4]Ambulance: 112\nPolice: 113\nFire: 115\nIf the numbers above don't work: Try the numbers for other services, 110 or 118. The disagreement among sources may reflect recent changes or variation throughout the country.\n\n\nCameroon: (available in major cities only)[5]Ambulance: 112 (try this first) or 119\nPolice: 117\nFire: 118\n\n\nCentral African Republic: 117\n\nChad: (may be unreliable or unavailable in most of country)\nAmbulance: unavailable\nPolice: 17\nFire: 18\n\n\nCongo, Democratic Republic of the: none available\n\nCongo, Republic of the: (45 minute response times in Brazzaville, services almost nonexistent in rest of country)[6]\nAll emergencies: 112 or +242 06 665-4804\n\nGabon:\nAmbulance: 1300\nPolice: 177 (some regions), 01-76-55-85 (in Libreville), 07-36-22-25 (in Port Gentil)\nFire: 01-76-15-20 (in Libreville), 07-63-93-63 (in Port Gentil)"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Western Africa. This includes all sub-Saharan countries in the Western region of Africa. For countries along the southwestern coast (south of the \"bend\"), see Central Africa above or Southern Africa below.\n\n\nBenin:\nAmbulance: Only local numbers available.\nPolice: 117\nFire: 118\n\n\nBurkina Faso: 10-10\n\nGambia: (emergency response teams often low on resources)\nAmbulance: 116\nPolice: 117 or (220) 422-4914\nFire: 118\n\n\nGhana: (many regions may require local numbers)\nAmbulance: 193 or 776111-5\nPolice: 191 or 999 or 171\nFire: 192\n\n\nGuinea: Only local numbers available.\n\nGuinea-Bisseau: (many regions may require local numbers)\nAmbulance: 119\nPolice: 121\nFire: 180\n\n\nIvory Coast: 111\n\nLiberia: 911 (very unreliable, and the country has no land-line telephones)\n\n\nMali: (many regions may require local numbers)\nAmbulance: 15 or 112\nPolice: 17 or 18\nFire: 17 or 18 or 112\n\n\nMauritania:\nAmbulance: 118 (Expect long delays; find alternate transport if possible)\n\nPolice: 117\nGendarmerie: 116 (military law enforcement, for use outside cities)\n\nFire: 118\nTraffic accidents: 117 or 119\n\n\nNiger:\nPolice: 17 or +227-20-72-25-53 (Unreliable, and only available during business hours)\n\nAmbulance and Fire: Unavailable\n\n\nNigeria:\nAmbulance, Police and Fire (Outside Lagos): 199\nAmbulance, Police and Fire (within Lagos): 112 or 767\n\n\nSenegal:\nPolice: 33-821-2431 or 800-00-20-20 or 800-00-17-00\nTourist Police: (221) 33 860-3810\nAmbulance and Fire: Unavailable\n\n\nSierra Leone: (many regions may require local numbers)\nAmbulance and Police: 999\nFire: 019\n\n\nTogo: 117"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Southern Africa. The following are emergency numbers for southern African countries:\n\n\nBotswana:\nAmbulance: 997\nPolice: 999\nFire: 998\n\n\nLesotho: (may be unreliable)\nPolice: (266) 2231 2934 or (266) 2232 2099\nOther services: Only local numbers available\n\n\nNamibia: 112\n\nSouth Africa: 10111\n\nSwaziland: 999"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Asian and Oceania Emergency Numbers",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in East Asia. This list includes China and surrounding countries in East Asia, including Japan.\n\n\nChina, mainland\nAmbulance: 120\nPolice: 110\nFire: 119\nTraffic accidents: 122\n\n\nChina, Republic of: See Taiwan\n\nHong Kong: 999\n\nMacau: 999\n\nJapan\nAmbulance or Fire: 119\nPolice: 110\n\n\nNorth Korea: May require local station number, but try 819, 112, or 119.[7][8]\n\nMongolia\nAmbulance: 103\nPolice: 102\nFire: 101\n\n\nSouth Korea:\nAmbulance or Fire: 119\nPolice: 112\n\n\nTaiwan\nAmbulance or Fire: 119\nPolice: 110"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in South Asia. The following numbers cover countries in the Indian subcontinent.\n\n\nAfghanistan\nAmbulance: 112 for Kabul (020-112 on a mobile phone). Outside of Kabul, local numbers only.\nPolice: 119 routes to Kabul, Kandahar, and Lashkar Gah. For local services elsewhere, you'll need a local number.\n\n\nBangladesh (may require local numbers outside of Dhaka and Chittagong)[9][10]Ambulance: 199 or 9-555-555 or 9132023 or 8122041\nPolice: 999-2222 or 9551188 or 9514400 or 01713398311\n\n\nBhutan[11]Ambulance or Medical Advice: 112\nPolice: 113\nFire: 110\nTraffic Accidents: 111\nIf none of the above work: Bhutan's emergency numbers are not consistently reported, possibly reflecting recent changes or variation throughout the country. If you can't get through, try the numbers listed for other services, or try 115.\n\n\nIndia\nAmbulance: 102\nPolice: 100\nFire: 101\nTraffic Accidents: 103\nAll emergencies: 108 (only available in some regions)\n\n\nMaldives\nAmbulance: 102\nPolice: 119\nFire: 118 or 108 or 999\n\n\nNepal\nAmbulance: 102 (run by a non-profit in greater Kathmandu and Patan), 4228094 (Red Cross in Kathmandu)[12]\n\nAmbulance in other regions: Contact a local ambulance or taxi.\nPolice: 100 or a local station\n\nFire: 101\n\n\nPakistan:[13]Ambulance: 115\nPolice: 15\nFire: 16\n\n\nSri Lanka:[14](some regions may require local numbers)\nAmbulance or Fire: 110 (or 011-2422222 in Colombo)\nPolice: 118 or 119 (or 011-2433333 in Colombo)\nTourist Police: 011-2421052"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Southeast Asia. Refer to this list for all countries east of Bangladesh and South of China, as well as countries in the Malay peninsula.\n\n\nBrunei:\nAmbulance: 991 or 222366\nPolice: 993 or 423901\nFire: 995 or 222555\n\n\nBurma: See Myanmar.\n\nCambodia:\nAmbulance: 119\nPolice: 117\nFire: 118\n\n\nIndonesia:\nAmbulance: 118 or 119\nPolice: 110 or 112\nFire: 113\n\n\nLaos:\nAmbulance: 195\nPolice: 191\nFire: 190\n\n\nMalaysia:\nPolice or Ambulance: 999\nFire: 999 or 994\nTourist police: 03 2149 6590\n\n\nMyanmar:\nAmbulance: 192\nPolice: 199\nFire: 191\n\n\nthe Philippines: 911\n\nSingapore:\nAmbulance or Fire: 995\nPolice: 999\n\n\nThailand:\nAmbulance or Police: 191\nFire: 199\n\n\nVietnam:\nAmbulance: 115\nPolice: 113\nFire: 114"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Central Asia. These countries are the landlocked countries in Central Asia. Note that Afghanistan is included in South Asia; Russia is included in Europe; and Mongolia is included in East Asia.\n\n\nKazakhstan: (may use 112, but will likely be directed to call one of the following)\nAmbulance: 103\nPolice: 102\nFire: 101\nGas Leak: 104\n\n\nKyrgyzstan:\nAmbulance: 103\nPolice: 102\nFire: 101\n\n\nTajikistan:\nAmbulance: 03\nPolice: 02\nFire: 01\n\n\nTurkmenistan: 03\n\nUzbekistan: (Add an initial 1 while in Tashkent city)\nAmbulance: 03\nPolice: 02\nFire: 01"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Oceania. This includes Australia and Pacific island nations. Note that Oceania nations with populations below 800,000 are not included.\n\n\nAustralia: 000\n\nFiji:\nAmbulance and Fire: 911\nPolice: 917\n\n\nNew Zealand: 111[15]\n\nPapua New Guinea: 111"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "European Emergency Numbers",
            "position": 4,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call 112 in most countries. Most European countries use 112 as the all-purpose emergency number, including every country in the European Union. Only countries that do not have the 112 number are listed below.\n\nMany countries have additional, country-specific emergency numbers, but 112 will direct you to the same services."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Southeastern Europe. Most countries here use 112, or are too small for inclusion on this list (less than one million people). Here are the larger exceptions:\n\n\nAlbania: 129 (emergency services are unreliable)\n\n\nBosnia and Herzegovina:\nAmbulance: 124\nPolice: 122\nFire: 123\n\n\nMacedonia:\nAmbulance: 194\nPolice: 192\n\n\nSerbia: (include the local area code if dialing from a mobile phone)\nAmbulance: 194\nPolice: 192\nFire: 193\nRoadside assistance: 1987\n\n\nTurkey:\nAll emergencies (including ambulance): 155\nAmbulance only: 112"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Eastern Europe. This includes former members of the Soviet Union and surrounding Slavic states. All states not listed below either use the number 112 or contain fewer than one million people.\n\n\nBelarus:\nAmbulance: 103\nPolice: 102\nFire: 101\n\n\nMoldova:\nAmbulance: 903\nPolice: 902\nFire: 901\n\n\nRussia:\nFire: 01 or 101\nPolice: 02 or 102\nAmbulance: 03 or 103\n\n\nUkraine: (expect long delays and poor service)\nAmbulance: 103\nPolice: 102\nFire: 101"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Northern, Central, or Western Europe. Almost all states in this region use the number 112 for all emergency services, although they may have alternate numbers that lead to the same result. Here are the only exceptions that affect more than one million people:\n\n\nNorway:\nAmbulance: 113\nPolice: 112\nFire: 110\n\n\nSwitzerland:\nGeneral: 112\nAmbulance: 144\nPolice: 117\nFire: 118\nToxic: 145 (You may want to call Ambulance first)\nAir Ambulance (REGA): 1414\n\n\nUK:999"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Central and South American Emergency Numbers",
            "position": 5,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in Central America. The following list includes all countries in the mainland of North America and south of Mexico, with a population greater than one million people.\n\n\nCosta Rica: 911\n\nEl Salvador: 911\n\nGuatemala:\nAmbulance or Fire: 123 or 122\nPolice: 110 or 120\n\n\nHonduras: (telephone service may be unreliable)\nAmbulance: 195 (Red Cross)\nPolice: 911 or 112\nFire: 198\n\n\nNicaragua:\nAmbulance: 128\nPolice: 118 (Spanish) or 101 (English tourism services)\nFire: 115 or 911\n\n\nPanama:\nAll emergencies: 911\nDirect to police: 104"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in South America. Here are emergency services for all countries with more than one million people on the South American continent.\n\n\nArgentina:\nCordoba, Mendoza, Iguazu, Tucuman, and Tierra del Fuego provinces: 101\nAll other provinces: 911\n\n\nBolivia: 110\n\nBrazil:\nAmbulance: 192\nPolice: 190\nFire: 193\n\n\nChile:\nAmbulance: 131\nPolice: 133\nFire: 132\n\n\nColombia: 123\n\nEcuador:\nQuito and Ibarra: 911\nGuayaquil, Cuenca and Loja,: 112\nElsewhere, Ambulance: 102 (or 131 for Red Cross)\nElsewhere, Police: 101\nElsewhere, Fire: 102\n\n\nParaguay:\nAll emergencies: 911\nDirect to Fire or Rescue: 131 or 132\n\n\nPeru:\nPolice: 105[16]\nFire: 116[17]\nAlternatives: Try 011 or 5114[18]\nTourist Protection: [19] 424 2053 (add initial area code 01 if outside of Lima)\n\n\nUruguay: 911\n\nVenezuela: 171"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Middle Eastern Emergency Numbers",
            "position": 6,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in the Middle East. This includes all countries in the Arabian peninsula and some surrounding countries. For Egypt, see Northern Africa. For Turkey, see Southeastern Europe.\n\n\nBahrain: 999\n\nIran:\nAmbulance: 115\nPolice: 110\nFire: 125\n\n\nIraq: 130 (including mobile telephones)\n\n\nIsrael:\nAmbulance: 101\nPolice: 100\nFire: 102\n(The West Bank and Gaza use the same numbers)\n\n\nJordan:\nAll emergencies: 191\nAlternate number, some parts of Amman: 911\n\n\nKuwait: 112\n\nLebanon: 112\n\nOman: 9999\n\nPalestine:\nAmbulance: 101\nPolice: 100\nFire: 102\n\n\nQatar: 999\n\nSaudi Arabia: 999\n\nSyria:\nAmbulance: 110\nPolice: 112\nFire: 113\n\n\nUnited Arab Emirates: 999\n\nYemen: 199"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "North American and Caribbean Emergency Numbers",
            "position": 7,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call 911 in most of North America. 911 is used by any country part of the North America Numbering Plan (NANP), including the United States, Canada, Bermuda, Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, Northern Marianas, Guam, American Samoa, and Sint Maarten.\n\n[20]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in North America. Note that mainland countries south of Mexico are listed under Central America.\n\n\nCanada: 911\n\nMexico: 066\n\nUnited States: 911"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Call in the Caribbean. All Caribbean nations with more than 350,000 people are listed here. Note that Martinique, Guadalupe, and several other islands are part of the French West Indies.\n\n\nCuba:\nAmbulance: 114 or 118[21](Expect long delays and poor service.[22] Most high-quality services use local numbers, may treat foreigners only, and may require payment in advance)\nPolice: 106\nFire: 105\n\n\nDominican Republic: 911\n\nFrench West Indies:\nAmbulance: 15\nPolice: 18\nFire: 17\n\n\nHaiti: 114\n\nJamaica: 119\n\nPuerto Rico: 911\n\nTrinidad and Tobago:\nAmbulance: 990 or 811 (or 694-2404 for private ambulance service)\nPolice: 999\nFire: 990"
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Call Emergency Services. For many countries in the world dialing 911, 999, or 112 from a mobile phone will connect you with emergency services. If that fails, this page lists mobile and landline emergency numbers for most countries..."
}</script>

content_html:
Try 911 or 112. These numbers work with many mobile service providers worldwide, due to efforts by the European Union and the United States. Try these first, unless a local knows a number that will work on mobile phones.
If that fails look up the emergency services number by continent and country below:
  • Africa
  • Asia and Oceania
  • Europe
  • Central and South America
  • Middle East
  • North America and Caribbean
Call in Northern Africa. These countries cover the Saharan desert and all African land north of it:
  • Algeria:
    • Ambulance: 021 – 23 63 81 or 021 – 71 14 14
    • Police: 17 (or 021 – 73 53 50 from a mobile)
    • Fire: 14 (or 021 – 71 14 14 from a mobile)
  • Canary Islands: 112
  • Egypt:
    • Ambulance: 123
    • Police: 122
    • Fire: 180
  • Libya: 193 (currently unreliable)
  • Morocco:
    • Ambulance or Fire: 15
    • Police: 19
  • Sudan: Only local numbers available
  • Tunisia:
    • Ambulance: 190
    • Police: 197
    • Fire: 198
Call in Eastern Africa. Here are emergency numbers for the Horn of Africa, and countries along the eastern half of Africa, including Madagascar.
  • Burundi: Only local numbers available
  • Djibouti:
    • Ambulance: 19
    • Police: 17
    • Fire: 18
  • Eritrea: Only local numbers available
  • Ethiopia:
    • Ambulance: 92
    • Police: 91
    • Fire: 93
  • Kenya:
    • All emergencies: 999
  • Madagascar:
    • Ambulance: 124
    • Police: 117
    • Fire: 118
    • Traffic Accidents: 3600
  • Malawi:
    • Ambulance: 998
    • Police: 997 or 990
    • Fire: 999
  • Mauritius:
    • Ambulance: 114
    • Police: 112 or 999
    • Fire: 115 or 995
  • Mozambique:
    • Ambulance: 117
    • Police: 119
    • Fire: 198
  • Rwanda:
    • Ambulance: 912
    • Police and Fire: 112
  • Somalia: (may be unreliable or absent in some regions)[1][2]
    • Ambulance: 999
    • Police: 888
    • Fire: 555
  • South Sudan:
    • Police: 777 (in Juba only)[3]
    • Ambulance and Fire: Unavailable
  • Tanzania: (may be unreliable; try local numbers)
    • Ambulance: 115
    • Police: 112
    • Fire: 114
  • Uganda: 999
  • Zambia: 999 or 991
  • Zimbabwe:
    • Ambulance: 994
    • Police: 777-777 (leads to Harare Central Station)
    • Fire: 993 or 783-983
    • Medical Air Relief: 771-221
Call in Central Africa. Look here for information on countries in Central Africa, and on the central western coast. (See Western Africa below for countries along the northwest coast.)
  • Angola:[4]
    • Ambulance: 112
    • Police: 113
    • Fire: 115
    • If the numbers above don't work: Try the numbers for other services, 110 or 118. The disagreement among sources may reflect recent changes or variation throughout the country.
  • Cameroon: (available in major cities only)[5]
    • Ambulance: 112 (try this first) or 119
    • Police: 117
    • Fire: 118
  • Central African Republic: 117
  • Chad: (may be unreliable or unavailable in most of country)
    • Ambulance: unavailable
    • Police: 17
    • Fire: 18
  • Congo, Democratic Republic of the: none available
  • Congo, Republic of the: (45 minute response times in Brazzaville, services almost nonexistent in rest of country)[6]
  • All emergencies: 112 or +242 06 665-4804
  • Gabon:
    • Ambulance: 1300
    • Police: 177 (some regions), 01-76-55-85 (in Libreville), 07-36-22-25 (in Port Gentil)
    • Fire: 01-76-15-20 (in Libreville), 07-63-93-63 (in Port Gentil)
Call in Western Africa. This includes all sub-Saharan countries in the Western region of Africa. For countries along the southwestern coast (south of the "bend"), see Central Africa above or Southern Africa below.
  • Benin:
    • Ambulance: Only local numbers available.
    • Police: 117
    • Fire: 118
  • Burkina Faso: 10-10
  • Gambia: (emergency response teams often low on resources)
    • Ambulance: 116
    • Police: 117 or (220) 422-4914
    • Fire: 118
  • Ghana: (many regions may require local numbers)
    • Ambulance: 193 or 776111-5
    • Police: 191 or 999 or 171
    • Fire: 192
  • Guinea: Only local numbers available.
  • Guinea-Bisseau: (many regions may require local numbers)
    • Ambulance: 119
    • Police: 121
    • Fire: 180
  • Ivory Coast: 111
  • Liberia: 911 (very unreliable, and the country has no land-line telephones)
  • Mali: (many regions may require local numbers)
    • Ambulance: 15 or 112
    • Police: 17 or 18
    • Fire: 17 or 18 or 112
  • Mauritania:
    • Ambulance: 118 (Expect long delays; find alternate transport if possible)
    • Police: 117
    • Gendarmerie: 116 (military law enforcement, for use outside cities)
    • Fire: 118
    • Traffic accidents: 117 or 119
  • Niger:
    • Police: 17 or +227-20-72-25-53 (Unreliable, and only available during business hours)
    • Ambulance and Fire: Unavailable
  • Nigeria:
    • Ambulance, Police and Fire (Outside Lagos): 199
    • Ambulance, Police and Fire (within Lagos): 112 or 767
  • Senegal:
    • Police: 33-821-2431 or 800-00-20-20 or 800-00-17-00
    • Tourist Police: (221) 33 860-3810
    • Ambulance and Fire: Unavailable
  • Sierra Leone: (many regions may require local numbers)
    • Ambulance and Police: 999
    • Fire: 019
  • Togo: 117
Call in Southern Africa. The following are emergency numbers for southern African countries:
  • Botswana:
    • Ambulance: 997
    • Police: 999
    • Fire: 998
  • Lesotho: (may be unreliable)
    • Police: (266) 2231 2934 or (266) 2232 2099
    • Other services: Only local numbers available
  • Namibia: 112
  • South Africa: 10111
  • Swaziland: 999
Call in East Asia. This list includes China and surrounding countries in East Asia, including Japan.
  • China, mainland
    • Ambulance: 120
    • Police: 110
    • Fire: 119
    • Traffic accidents: 122
  • China, Republic of: See Taiwan
  • Hong Kong: 999
  • Macau: 999
  • Japan
    • Ambulance or Fire: 119
    • Police: 110
  • North Korea: May require local station number, but try 819, 112, or 119.[7][8]
  • Mongolia
    • Ambulance: 103
    • Police: 102
    • Fire: 101
  • South Korea:
    • Ambulance or Fire: 119
    • Police: 112
  • Taiwan
    • Ambulance or Fire: 119
    • Police: 110
Call in South Asia. The following numbers cover countries in the Indian subcontinent.
  • Afghanistan
    • Ambulance: 112 for Kabul (020-112 on a mobile phone). Outside of Kabul, local numbers only.
    • Police: 119 routes to Kabul, Kandahar, and Lashkar Gah. For local services elsewhere, you'll need a local number.
  • Bangladesh (may require local numbers outside of Dhaka and Chittagong)[9][10]
    • Ambulance: 199 or 9-555-555 or 9132023 or 8122041
    • Police: 999-2222 or 9551188 or 9514400 or 01713398311
  • Bhutan[11]
    • Ambulance or Medical Advice: 112
    • Police: 113
    • Fire: 110
    • Traffic Accidents: 111
    • If none of the above work: Bhutan's emergency numbers are not consistently reported, possibly reflecting recent changes or variation throughout the country. If you can't get through, try the numbers listed for other services, or try 115.
  • India
    • Ambulance: 102
    • Police: 100
    • Fire: 101
    • Traffic Accidents: 103

    • Ambulance: 102
    • Police: 119
    • Fire: 118 or 108 or 999
  • Nepal
    • Ambulance: 102 (run by a non-profit in greater Kathmandu and Patan), 4228094 (Red Cross in Kathmandu)[12]
    • Ambulance in other regions: Contact a local ambulance or taxi.
    • Police: 100 or a local station
    • Fire: 101
  • Pakistan:[13]
    • Ambulance: 115
    • Police: 15
    • Fire: 16
  • Sri Lanka:[14](some regions may require local numbers)
    • Ambulance or Fire: 110 (or 011-2422222 in Colombo)
    • Police: 118 or 119 (or 011-2433333 in Colombo)
    • Tourist Police: 011-2421052
Call in Southeast Asia. Refer to this list for all countries east of Bangladesh and South of China, as well as countries in the Malay peninsula.

  • Myanmar:

    • Police: 199
    • Fire: 191
  • the Philippines: 911
  • Singapore:
    • Ambulance or Fire: 995
    • Police: 999
  • Thailand:
    • Ambulance or Police: 191
    • Fire: 199
  • Vietnam:
    • Ambulance: 115
    • Police: 113
    • Fire: 114
Call in Central Asia. These countries are the landlocked countries in Central Asia. Note that Afghanistan is included in South Asia; Russia is included in Europe; and Mongolia is included in East Asia.
  • Kazakhstan: (may use 112, but will likely be directed to call one of the following)
    • Ambulance: 103
    • Police: 102
    • Fire: 101

  • Kyrgyzstan:
    • Ambulance: 103
    • Police: 102
    • Fire: 101
  • Tajikistan:
    • Ambulance: 03
    • Police: 02
    • Fire: 01
  • Turkmenistan: 03
  • Uzbekistan: (Add an initial 1 while in Tashkent city)
    • Ambulance: 03
    • Police: 02
    • Fire: 01
Call in Oceania. This includes Australia and Pacific island nations. Note that Oceania nations with populations below 800,000 are not included.
  • Australia: 000
  • Fiji:
    • Ambulance and Fire: 911
    • Police: 917
  • New Zealand: 111[15]
  • Papua New Guinea: 111
Call 112 in most countries. Most European countries use 112 as the all-purpose emergency number, including every country in the European Union. Only countries that do not have the 112 number are listed below.
  • Many countries have additional, country-specific emergency numbers, but 112 will direct you to the same services.
Call in Southeastern Europe. Most countries here use 112, or are too small for inclusion on this list (less than one million people). Here are the larger exceptions:
  • Albania: 129 (emergency services are unreliable)
  • Bosnia and Herzegovina:
    • Ambulance: 124
    • Police: 122
    • Fire: 123
  • Macedonia:
    • Ambulance: 194
    • Police: 192
  • Serbia: (include the local area code if dialing from a mobile phone)
    • Ambulance: 194
    • Police: 192
    • Fire: 193
    • Roadside assistance: 1987
  • Turkey:
    • All emergencies (including ambulance): 155
    • Ambulance only: 112
Call in Eastern Europe. This includes former members of the Soviet Union and surrounding Slavic states. All states not listed below either use the number 112 or contain fewer than one million people.
  • Belarus:
    • Ambulance: 103
    • Police: 102
    • Fire: 101
  • Moldova:
    • Ambulance: 903
    • Police: 902
    • Fire: 901
  • Russia:
    • Fire: 01 or 101
    • Police: 02 or 102
    • Ambulance: 03 or 103
  • Ukraine: (expect long delays and poor service)
    • Ambulance: 103
    • Police: 102
    • Fire: 101
Call in Northern, Central, or Western Europe. Almost all states in this region use the number 112 for all emergency services, although they may have alternate numbers that lead to the same result. Here are the only exceptions that affect more than one million people:
  • Norway:
    • Ambulance: 113
    • Police: 112
    • Fire: 110
  • Switzerland:
    • General: 112
    • Ambulance: 144
    • Police: 117
    • Fire: 118
    • Toxic: 145 (You may want to call Ambulance first)
    • Air Ambulance (REGA): 1414
  • UK:999
Call in Central America. The following list includes all countries in the mainland of North America and south of Mexico, with a population greater than one million people.
  • Costa Rica: 911
  • El Salvador: 911
  • Guatemala:
    • Ambulance or Fire: 123 or 122
    • Police: 110 or 120
  • Honduras: (telephone service may be unreliable)
    • Ambulance: 195 (Red Cross)
    • Police: 911 or 112
    • Fire: 198
  • Nicaragua:
    • Ambulance: 128
    • Police: 118 (Spanish) or 101 (English tourism services)
    • Fire: 115 or 911
  • Panama:
    • All emergencies: 911
    • Direct to police: 104
Call in South America. Here are emergency services for all countries with more than one million people on the South American continent.
  • Argentina:
    • Cordoba, Mendoza, Iguazu, Tucuman, and Tierra del Fuego provinces: 101
    • All other provinces: 911
  • Bolivia: 110
  • Brazil:
    • Ambulance: 192
    • Police: 190
    • Fire: 193
  • Chile:
    • Ambulance: 131
    • Police: 133
    • Fire: 132
  • Colombia: 123
  • Ecuador:
    • Quito and Ibarra: 911
    • Guayaquil, Cuenca and Loja,: 112
    • Elsewhere, Ambulance: 102 (or 131 for Red Cross)
    • Elsewhere, Police: 101
    • Elsewhere, Fire: 102
  • Paraguay:
    • All emergencies: 911
    • Direct to Fire or Rescue: 131 or 132
  • Peru:
    • Police: 105[16]
    • Fire: 116[17]
    • Alternatives: Try 011 or 5114[18]
    • Tourist Protection: [19] 424 2053 (add initial area code 01 if outside of Lima)
  • Uruguay: 911
  • Venezuela: 171
Call in the Middle East. This includes all countries in the Arabian peninsula and some surrounding countries. For Egypt, see Northern Africa. For Turkey, see Southeastern Europe.
  • Bahrain: 999
  • Iran:
    • Ambulance: 115
    • Police: 110
    • Fire: 125
  • Iraq: 130 (including mobile telephones)
  • Israel:
    • Ambulance: 101
    • Police: 100
    • Fire: 102
    • (The West Bank and Gaza use the same numbers)
  • Jordan:
    • All emergencies: 191
    • Alternate number, some parts of Amman: 911
  • Kuwait: 112
  • Lebanon: 112
  • Oman: 9999
  • Palestine:
    • Ambulance: 101
    • Police: 100
    • Fire: 102
  • Qatar: 999
  • Saudi Arabia: 999
  • Syria:
    • Ambulance: 110
    • Police: 112
    • Fire: 113
  • United Arab Emirates: 999
  • Yemen: 199
Call 911 in most of North America. 911 is used by any country part of the North America Numbering Plan (NANP), including the United States, Canada, Bermuda, Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, Northern Marianas, Guam, American Samoa, and Sint Maarten. [20]
Call in North America. Note that mainland countries south of Mexico are listed under Central America.
  • Canada: 911
  • Mexico: 066
  • United States: 911
Call in the Caribbean. All Caribbean nations with more than 350,000 people are listed here. Note that Martinique, Guadalupe, and several other islands are part of the French West Indies.
  • Cuba:
    • Ambulance: 114 or 118[21](Expect long delays and poor service.[22] Most high-quality services use local numbers, may treat foreigners only, and may require payment in advance)
    • Police: 106
    • Fire: 105
  • Dominican Republic: 911
  • French West Indies:
    • Ambulance: 15
    • Police: 18
    • Fire: 17
  • Haiti: 114
  • Jamaica: 119
  • Puerto Rico: 911
  • Trinidad and Tobago:
    • Ambulance: 990 or 811 (or 694-2404 for private ambulance service)
    • Police: 999
    • Fire: 990
content: Try 911 or 112. These numbers work with many mobile service providers worldwide, due to efforts by the European Union and the United States. Try these first, unless a local knows a number that will work on mobile phones. If that fails look up the emergency services number by continent and country below: Africa Asia and Oceania Europe Central and South America Middle East North America and Caribbean Call in Northern Africa . These countries cover the Saharan desert and all African land north of it: Algeria : Ambulance: 021 – 23 63 81 or 021 – 71 14 14 Police: 17 (or 021 – 73 53 50 from a mobile) Fire: 14 (or 021 – 71 14 14 from a mobile) Canary Islands : 112 Egypt : Ambulance: 123 Police: 122 Fire: 180 Libya: 193 (currently unreliable) Morocco: Ambulance or Fire: 15 Police: 19 Sudan: Only local numbers available Tunisia: Ambulance: 190 Police: 197 Fire: 198 Call in Eastern Africa . Here are emergency numbers for the Horn of Africa, and countries along the eastern half of Africa, including Madagascar. Burundi: Only local numbers available Djibouti : Ambulance: 19 Police: 17 Fire: 18 Eritrea : Only local numbers available Ethiopia: Ambulance: 92 Police: 91 Fire: 93 Kenya: All emergencies: 999 Madagascar: Ambulance: 124 Police: 117 Fire: 118 Traffic Accidents: 3600 Malawi: Ambulance: 998 Police: 997 or 990 Fire: 999 Mauritius: Ambulance: 114 Police: 112 or 999 Fire: 115 or 995 Mozambique: Ambulance: 117 Police: 119 Fire: 198 Rwanda: Ambulance: 912 Police and Fire: 112 Somalia: (may be unreliable or absent in some regions) [1] [2] Ambulance: 999 Police: 888 Fire: 555 South Sudan: Police: 777 (in Juba only) [3] Ambulance and Fire: Unavailable Tanzania: (may be unreliable; try local numbers ) Ambulance: 115 Police: 112 Fire: 114 Uganda: 999 Zambia: 999 or 991 Zimbabwe: Ambulance: 994 Police: 777-777 (leads to Harare Central Station) Fire: 993 or 783-983 Medical Air Relief: 771-221 Call in Central Africa . Look here for information on countries in Central Africa, and on the central western coast. (See Western Africa below for countries along the northwest coast.) Angola: [4] Ambulance: 112 Police: 113 Fire: 115 If the numbers above don't work: Try the numbers for other services, 110 or 118. The disagreement among sources may reflect recent changes or variation throughout the country. Cameroon : (available in major cities only) [5] Ambulance: 112 (try this first) or 119 Police: 117 Fire: 118 Central African Republic: 117 Chad: (may be unreliable or unavailable in most of country) Ambulance: unavailable Police: 17 Fire: 18 Congo, Democratic Republic of the : none available Congo, Republic of the: (45 minute response times in Brazzaville, services almost nonexistent in rest of country) [6] All emergencies: 112 or +242 06 665-4804 Gabon: Ambulance: 1300 Police: 177 (some regions), 01-76-55-85 (in Libreville), 07-36-22-25 (in Port Gentil) Fire: 01-76-15-20 (in Libreville), 07-63-93-63 (in Port Gentil) Call in Western Africa . This includes all sub-Saharan countries in the Western region of Africa. For countries along the southwestern coast (south of the "bend"), see Central Africa above or Southern Africa below. Benin: Ambulance: Only local numbers available. Police: 117 Fire: 118 Burkina Faso: 10-10 Gambia: (emergency response teams often low on resources) Ambulance: 116 Police: 117 or (220) 422-4914 Fire: 118 Ghana: (many regions may require local numbers) Ambulance: 193 or 776111-5 Police: 191 or 999 or 171 Fire: 192 Guinea: Only local numbers available. Guinea-Bisseau : (many regions may require local numbers) Ambulance: 119 Police: 121 Fire: 180 Ivory Coast: 111 Liberia: 911 (very unreliable, and the country has no land-line telephones) Mali: (many regions may require local numbers) Ambulance: 15 or 112 Police: 17 or 18 Fire: 17 or 18 or 112 Mauritania: Ambulance: 118 (Expect long delays; find alternate transport if possible) Police: 117 Gendarmerie: 116 (military law enforcement, for use outside cities) Fire: 118 Traffic accidents: 117 or 119 Niger: Police: 17 or +227-20-72-25-53 (Unreliable, and only available during business hours) Ambulance and Fire: Unavailable Nigeria: Ambulance, Police and Fire (Outside Lagos): 199 Ambulance, Police and Fire (within Lagos): 112 or 767 Senegal: Police: 33-821-2431 or 800-00-20-20 or 800-00-17-00 Tourist Police: (221) 33 860-3810 Ambulance and Fire: Unavailable Sierra Leone: (many regions may require local numbers) Ambulance and Police: 999 Fire: 019 Togo: 117 Call in Southern Africa . The following are emergency numbers for southern African countries: Botswana: Ambulance: 997 Police: 999 Fire: 998 Lesotho: (may be unreliable) Police: (266) 2231 2934 or (266) 2232 2099 Other services: Only local numbers available Namibia: 112 South Africa: 10111 Swaziland: 999 Call in East Asia . This list includes China and surrounding countries in East Asia, including Japan. China, mainland Ambulance: 120 Police: 110 Fire: 119 Traffic accidents: 122 China, Republic of : See Taiwan Hong Kong: 999 Macau: 999 Japan Ambulance or Fire: 119 Police: 110 North Korea : May require local station number, but try 819, 112, or 119. [7] [8] Mongolia Ambulance: 103 Police: 102 Fire: 101 South Korea : Ambulance or Fire: 119 Police: 112 Taiwan Ambulance or Fire: 119 Police: 110 Call in South Asia . The following numbers cover countries in the Indian subcontinent. Afghanistan Ambulance: 112 for Kabul (020-112 on a mobile phone). Outside of Kabul, local numbers only. Police: 119 routes to Kabul, Kandahar, and Lashkar Gah. For local services elsewhere, you'll need a local number. Bangladesh (may require local numbers outside of Dhaka and Chittagong) [9] [10] Ambulance: 199 or 9-555-555 or 9132023 or 8122041 Police: 999-2222 or 9551188 or 9514400 or 01713398311 Bhutan [11] Ambulance or Medical Advice: 112 Police: 113 Fire: 110 Traffic Accidents: 111 If none of the above work: Bhutan's emergency numbers are not consistently reported, possibly reflecting recent changes or variation throughout the country. If you can't get through, try the numbers listed for other services, or try 115. Refer to this list for all countries east of Bangladesh and South of China, as well as countries in the Malay peninsula. Brunei : Ambulance: 991 or 222366 Police: 993 or 423901 Fire: 995 or 222555 Burma : See Myanmar. Cambodia : Ambulance: 119 Police: 117 Fire: 118 Indonesia: Ambulance: 118 or 119 Police: 110 or 112 Fire: 113 Laos: Ambulance: 195 Police: 191 Fire: 190 Malaysia: Police or Ambulance: 999 Fire: 999 or 994 Tourist police: 03 2149 6590 Myanmar: Ambulance: 192 Police: 199 Fire: 191 the Philippines: 911 Singapore: Ambulance or Fire: 995 Police: 999 Thailand: Ambulance or Police: 191 Fire: 199 Vietnam: Ambulance: 115 Police: 113 Fire: 114 Call in Central Asia . These countries are the landlocked countries in Central Asia. Note that Afghanistan is included in South Asia; Russia is included in Europe; and Mongolia is included in East Asia. Kazakhstan: (may use 112, but will likely be directed to call one of the following) Ambulance: 103 Police: 102 Fire: 101 Gas Leak: 104 Kyrgyzstan: Ambulance: 103 Police: 102 Fire: 101 Tajikistan: Ambulance: 03 Police: 02 Fire: 01 Turkmenistan: 03 Uzbekistan: (Add an initial 1 while in Tashkent city) Ambulance: 03 Police: 02 Fire: 01 Call in Oceania . This includes Australia and Pacific island nations. Note that Oceania nations with populations below 800,000 are not included. Australia : 000 Fiji : Ambulance and Fire: 911 Police: 917 New Zealand : 111 [15] Papua New Guinea : 111 Call 112 in most countries. Most European countries use 112 as the all-purpose emergency number, including every country in the European Union. Only countries that do not have the 112 number are listed below. Many countries have additional, country-specific emergency numbers, but 112 will direct you to the same services. Call in Southeastern Europe . Most countries here use 112, or are too small for inclusion on this list (less than one million people). Here are the larger exceptions: Albania: 129 (emergency services are unreliable) Bosnia and Herzegovina: Ambulance: 124 Police: 122 Fire: 123 Macedonia: Ambulance: 194 Police: 192 Serbia: (include the local area code if dialing from a mobile phone) Ambulance: 194 Police: 192 Fire: 193 Roadside assistance: 1987 Turkey: All emergencies (including ambulance): 155 Ambulance only: 112 Call in Eastern Europe . This includes former members of the Soviet Union and surrounding Slavic states. All states not listed below either use the number 112 or contain fewer than one million people. Belarus: Ambulance: 103 Police: 102 Fire: 101 Moldova: Ambulance: 903 Police: 902 Fire: 901 Russia: Fire: 01 or 101 Police: 02 or 102 Ambulance: 03 or 103 Ukraine: (expect long delays and poor service) Ambulance: 103 Police: 102 Fire: 101 Call in Northern, Central, or Western Europe . Almost all states in this region use the number 112 for all emergency services, although they may have alternate numbers that lead to the same result. Here are the only exceptions that affect more than one million people: Norway: Ambulance: 113 Police: 112 Fire: 110 Switzerland: General: 112 Ambulance: 144 Police: 117 Fire: 118 Toxic: 145 (You may want to call Ambulance first) Air Ambulance (REGA): 1414 UK:999 Call in Central America . The following list includes all countries in the mainland of North America and south of Mexico, with a population greater than one million people. Costa Rica : 911 El Salvador : 911 Guatemala : Ambulance or Fire: 123 or 122 Police: 110 or 120 Honduras : (telephone service may be unreliable) Ambulance: 195 (Red Cross) Police: 911 or 112 Fire: 198 Nicaragua : Ambulance: 128 Police: 118 (Spanish) or 101 (English tourism services) Fire: 115 or 911 Panama : All emergencies: 911 Direct to police: 104 Call in South America. Here are emergency services for all countries with more than one million people on the South American continent. This includes all countries in the Arabian peninsula and some surrounding countries. For Egypt, see Northern Africa. For Turkey, see Southeastern Europe.
